Today, Kaito introduced new reputation thresholds for all project leaderboards (including our favorite, Billions). 
Because of this, some of the top creators who were previously on the main Creator Leaderboard have moved to the Wider Community Leaderboard.

Why @billions_ntwk is Built as Public Infrastructure

Proving you're a real person shouldn't be controlled by one company or locked behind some proprietary system.

It should be something we all share open for anyone to use and build on top of. Any app, protocol, or network should be able to tap into it without needing permission or paying tolls to a gatekeeper.

That's the whole point of Billions. We're not building another walled garden. We're building something that belongs to everyone public infrastructure for the internet.

In an open ecosystem; it's typically quite difficult to know which issuer(s) to trust.

Billions {@billions_ntwk} aims to fix this by employing a "Trust Registries." These registries are effectively smart contracts or public lists that curate trusted issuers.

A verifier (like a dApp) on the network does not need to manually check or vet every issuer; they can set rules that accept credentials from any issuer listed in a particular Trust Registry.

In a nutshell; this governance layer on Billions makes the decentralized system easily scalable and manageable.

The Billions [@billions_ntwk] architecture supports Key Rotation; how this works is that, basically, a user's identity (DID) is separate from the keys that control it. 

So, if a private key is compromised, the user can rotate to a new key without losing their identifier or the reputation attached to it.

This ensures long-term identity continuity even in the face of critical security incidents.

key points about @billions_ntwk  you should know: ü´µüèª
 
1. Purpose 
Billions is a decentralized trust network aimed at enabling verifiable identities and reputations for AI agents. 
 
2. Foundation 
Built on Privado ID technology, leveraging decentralized identifiers (DIDs) and verifiable credentials (VCs). 
 
3. Core Problem 
Addresses the lack of verifiable identity for AI agents, which hampers accountability and trust in human-to-agent (H2A) and agent-to-agent (A2A) interactions. 
 
4. Identity Dimensions 
Defines four identity dimensions for AI agents: architectural, behavioral, legal, and social identity. 
 
5. Architectural Identity 
Based on the model‚Äôs structure, weights, code, cryptographic fingerprints, and runtime environment. 
 
6. Behavioral Identity 
Links identifiers to dynamic agent behavior; future-proofed for zero-knowledge machine learning (zkML) developments. 
 
7. Legal Identity 
Connects AI agents to recognized owners or operators via legal attestations, digital certificates, and compliance frameworks. 
 
8. Social Identity 
Captures reputation through endorsements, public attestations, and transparency signals. 
 
9. Identifiers 
Uses decentralized key-based identifiers (DIDs, blockchain addresses, X.509 certificates) with cryptographic signing for proof of control. 
 
10. Hybrid Verification Model 
Combines on-chain public attestations and off-chain private identity wallets to balance transparency and privacy. 
 
11. Universal On-chain Registry 
A cross-chain, zero-knowledge-enabled registry for publishing immutable attestations about AI agents and humans. 
 
12. Privacy & Unlinkability 
Supports zero-knowledge proofs and pairwise DIDs to enable privacy-preserving, unlinkable attestations. 
 
13. Agent Ownership 
Establishes ‚Äúfoundational attestations‚Äù linking an agent to its creator or owner, enabling claims of ownership, transfers, and revocations. 
 
14. Reputation Graph 
Builds composite reputations through attestations and relationships (e.g., developer, trainer, auditor), enabling rich trust profiles. 
 
15. Governance 
Supports decentralized trust registries, potentially managed by DAOs or other governance models to maintain credibility. 
 
16. Tooling Ecosystem 
Provides identity wallets, issuer toolsets, and verifier toolsets for seamless creation, management, and verification of credentials. 
 
17. Future Direction 
Positioned for scalability and evolution with zkML, decentralized reputation models, and interoperable trust ecosystems for AI. 
 
Which part excites you the most???
